												Cinders is a pretty fantastic visual novel, full of strong female characters and decisions that have consequences. It's a darker, more mature take on the classic Cinderella fairy tale, but with some clever twists. The artwork and music are really gorgeous and add a lot to the story. It's also worth noting that this is one of the rare visual novels that uses an art style other than anime.The game's a bit short and even going back and playing several endings won't take much longer than a few hours. Unfortunately, there isn't a lot of replay value. While there are a lot of different endings in the game, things become a little tedious after you've played through a couple of times. Other than achievement hunting, there's not much payoff for getting all the endings.Even though it's brief, the story and characters are engaging and it's an enjoyable experience while it lasts. It's also a visual novel that's a bit heavier on the novel part than straight-up dating sims; several different pairings can occur, but the focus isn't entirely on romance.I personally think that the $20 price tag is a little steep for such a short game though, so look for sales or bundle deals.

												I'm really interested in visual novels, particularly ones aimed at women, so I've been trying to make a point of everything available in English. I have to say, this is probably the best one I've seen so far.The aesthetics of this game are amazing. The art is beautiful, as you can see from the screenshots, but something they don't show is how everything looks in movement. The backgrounds are subtly animated and the text appears on the screen in a magical shine of color. It's mostly small touches, but it makes the game feel very unique from a lot of other indie visual novels that originally came out in English.Another thing that makes Cinders really stand out is the way they show you how your choices are affecting the game. Every time a line is changed due to one of your choices, a chime plays and a symbol appears in the corner. Once you reach certain goals (which you gain achievements for on Steam) the starting menu will change to show your awards. And after you reach an ending, there's a screen that shows you all the possible variables in the ending you achieved. I'm impressed to see that it looks like there's a LOT of variables in the ending I got, which makes me really interested in what other possibilities there are! (It should also help the game have lots of value as well--my first playthrough was probably around three hours or so, so I'm expecting to get a good amount of playtime in to complete all the endings and branching paths...10-15 hours is what I'm estimating right now.) I was also impressed by the number of choices present in the game--they happen frequently, and never feel pointlessly shoved in. I don't know how well the illusion of choice will hold up in further playthroughs but at least in this first one I really felt like my choices had an impact, which makes me very pleased.As for the story--I loved it. Nearly all of the characters are interesting and have different layers to uncover from what I've seen in the game so far. I particularly like what's been done with the stepsisters--the game doesn't quite make excuses for them, but does a lot to make it make sense why they'd be so cruel to Cinders. Finding out more about Sophia in particular (who is probably my favorite character) is something I'm looking forward to trying to uncover in later playthroughs.If I had one complaint, the only thing I could come up with is that at times the game's dialogue clashes with the tone they seem to be going for. They're trying to make the story feel like it's in a historical place--one where there are elements of fantasy, but that could otherwise reasonably exist at some point in history. But a lot of the dialogue feels oddly modern and even occasionally slang-y. I don't think this is exactly a problem, but it does clash at times with their attempts to make things feel 'historical.' But honestly, that's a nitpick, and one I gave partially so this review wouldn't be completely glowing. Otherwise, this is probably the best Visual Novel I've played, hands down. I'm glad it's finally showed up on Steam.

												As far as visual novels go, I have to say that CINDERS is my favorite, thus far.  The game takes the player down a very mature path within a classic children's fairytale.  The player has complete control over the decision making process of the main character.  Thus, with each choice the player makes for Cinders, her personality changes as the game progresses.  There is a large number of outcomes for this character based on those decisions she is presented with throughout the game.  For instance, with the decisions the player chooses for Cinders, she could become very evil or good, very sexual or timid, and/or anywhere in between.  I honestly couldn't believe the number of outcomes this game presents the player with!  The replayability is enormous.  The artwork is absolutely gorgeous.  The music is beautiful.  I applaud how the devs implemented the 'fast forward scene' ability within the game as even though this is a VN, thus a lot of reading, it allows the player to choose whether to read through a scene over and over if they wish OR fast forward through a scene that they have previously experienced.  Please remember, there are NUMEROUS outcomes to this game and over 300 different possible decisions to be made (at minimum)!  The player can also choose the rate of speed that the dialogue is presented, which gives the player a chance to choose either the slower paced dialogue which visually allows 'emphasis' placed on certain words or phrases 'spoken' by each character OR to speed it up and read at the players pace.  I literally just finished the very last outcome for this game before writing this review.  I sat back and just said "WOW!"  (yes, it's that good!)  I highly recommend this game to any VN lover --- and would really like to see others at least give it a shot.  It truly is a very well thought out game!!!

"Rook di goo, rook di goo! No blood's in the shoe. The shoe's not too tight, This bride is right!" - Cinderella, Jacob and Wilhelm GrimmAs the first of Moacube's visual novels, Cinders is a roaring success both for its genre and as an example of literary deconstruction. I've been meaning to play this game for years, and now I did, I cannot stop myself from taking new playthroughs to unlock all ending variants, to see what else this game may have in store for me. This unconventional interpretation of the classical folktale Cinderella breaks all stereotypes and social generalizations, presenting an in-depth analysis of all its characters and probable intervening dynamics. Kudos to the developer upfront!At this point, everyone with a semi-European cultural understanding is familiar with the story of Cinderella. Poor, golden hearted young woman who is treated like a slave in her own home by her ambitious stepmother and evil stepsisters. All her kindness only meets with mistreatment until a fairy godmother appears to bless her with a magical dress, a pumpkin carriage and glass slippers to attend the ball of the Prince. There, she is to steal Prince's heart with a glance and become the queen of the kingdom after a short pursuit involving those glass slippers. There, happily ever after, right? Nope, not so much. The original story was a brutal one compared to the Disney-fied version anyhow, and with Cinders now, we are in for a more realistic version of the old fairytale.Here, our protagonist' conditions are more or less the same with the original story. Her father has passed away, and now she is living with her stepmother and two stepsisters, whom treat her little better than a servant. She wishes to change her life, take the control of her future and decide the outcome of her own story though, rather than waiting for magic to happen! Sure, waiting for magic to happen is still our option, but just one of our options nonetheless. We are to live through a week of Cinders to witness the events just before the guard captain of his majesty knocks on our door. What happened to present such a necessity? Now, that is gonna be our choice. We will create a Cinders of our own. We'll make various choices, pick how to act towards whom and what to pursue in the way we chose. Eventually, we will meet one of the various endings appropriate for our personality.In this glamorous visual novel, every single choice sincerely matters. Our actions determine our romance option - yup, we don't have to go happily ever after with the prince - , our character and eventually our own ending. Every single character involving - whether their role in the original story were small or grand - are reimagined into actual people, with their own personalities, background and aspirations. Did you ever think why the stepmother treated Cinderella the way she did? Just because she was evil? Or did you ever take a second glance at the captain of the guards? Why the fairy actually aided our girl the way she did? Because that's what fairies are supposed to do? Definitely not! Here, you are presented with a decent analysis of the story, stripped away from its embellishment and take a realistic approach to the situation, wrapped in genuine medieval context. The result is an incredible story with layers of characterization and perfect narrative with philosophical value.The display is topnotch. All the artwork - both characters and the environment are fitting for a fairytale alright. Yet, this is not the strongest suit of the display. All character CG are presented in a way to maintain noteworthy body language and facial mimics, fortifying the narrative furthermore. Add a breathtaking soundtrack with various instrumental pieces of folk and epic music, and voila: here is a display environment you wouldn't grow tired of playing over and over again.Now, I've already noted that endings are various. There are mainly 4 endings: one fairytale, one lady of the house, one “whatever, I'm out of this place" and one "not so happy". All these endings carry their own varieties within themselves however. According to the romance you pursue, the way you treated people and the amount of information you managed to gather by the end, you'll get a different variety of these endings. Every one of them can be tracked and re-read in the menu too.At the end, Cinders is one of the most imaginative, deep and successfully displayed visual novels that I've ever played. Even if you are not a fan of the genre, you may enjoy this one thanks to its narrative quality, depth and even sense of humor! At this point, I'll be looking forward for any VN that Moacube would throw my way. Enjoy!Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

												With some regret, I have to say that I do not recommend this game. I really wanted to like this game; the premise was promising and the art style is beautiful (though the scenes are limited; don't expect much variety). This visual novel has the makings of a great novel--great artwork, interesting characters, a wealth of different options, the ability to skip scenes easily on a second playthrough (viewing only the new content you haven't seen before), and most importantly to me, your choices change the outcome of your story. Every choice matters. The only real fault I had with this game was the atrocious writing. It was painful--unrealistic language, blatant foreshadowing, laughable and sometimes downright confusing conversations. The makers of this game went so far into making sure that the player was aware of the nuances of each character that they beat you over the head with them, and then beat the horse you rode in on too. I like subtle, complex characterization, and character growth should be something developed over time and with a touch more realism. Rather than creating nuanced dialogue the game screams it at you, and then has the main character repeat it to herself in her alone time just to make sure you didn't misunderstand anything.I paid $4 for this game via Humble Bundle , and spend roughly 3 hours doing two playthroughs (with numerous bouts of getting up for pizza and tea). If I had paid $20 via steam, I suspect my review would be that much more vitriolic...if you go to the effort of making a well-crafted game, you should spend some time crafting the text with the same dexterity shown elsewhere.

												It's rather unusual to see a visual novel coming from somewhere other than Japan that doesn't attempt to merely emulate those that do, but instead takes hold of the genre and carves a unique path for itself that shows VNs have a lot more to offer than we've thus seen. In the case of Cinders, it also manages to update a classic fairytail into a far more mature and modern story, turning Cinderella into a newly captivating adventurer that eschews many of the originals childish elements for mystery and intrigue. It stumbles a bit along the way, as if walking in its own pair of undersized glass slippers, but on the whole amounts to something unexpectedly enthralling and maybe just a bit magical.I can't imagine anyone is unfamiliar with the story of Cinderella, so I'll skip the introductions. The vile mother and sisters, sad girl living as a servant waiting for the world to change, glass slippers and prince charming are all here as you'd expect, but where Cinders differs is in taking a simple fairy tail and turning it into a mature and intriguing story that is wildly different than how you remember it. Character interactions are full of personal dialogue and emotion, turning the original cliches into actual people you can relate and empathize with. Cinders sisters might be cold, but once their reasons are explained it's hard not to feel sorry for them despite their cruelties. The prince may appear to live a life of carefree amusement, but on the inside his constant questioning of his actions is tearing him apart and making him question his own motives. There are certainly moments when it becomes overly self indulgent with some of its writing, and a few endings feel a bit hollow (though that's to be expected with how many there are), but these moments are overshadowed by the majority of the dialog, which is hugely engrossing and when compiled with the element of your own choices becomes even more compelling, as you shape the outcome to any number of different paths.Which brings me to one of the few areas Cinders slips up a bit, at least in the view of someone who wishes to see more than the one ending they arrive at. Throughout the story (which should take you around 2-5 hours depending on your reading speed) you encounter a myriad of choices which change the story and eventually decide your characters fate. The issue arises in the sheer number of decisions that can have an impact on the ending, and the very limited number of saves you are given, which means you are required to skip through huge amounts of text again and again as you reload and make minor alterations to your choices in the attempts to see a new ending. It all becomes greatly repetitive and takes far more time than it otherwise might had you been given more freedom in the number of saves you have, as well as making it quicker to skip through dialog you've already read before.But ultimately it's a somewhat inconsequential complaint as for those not obsessed with seeing every ending, the first run through the story isn't the least bit affected and just as captivating as ever. Least I forget Cinders is also remarkably pretty to look at, with fantastic art and a ton of minor details bringing the picture to life, from background objects to character expressions. It's a bold new direction for visual novels, a genre that's been stagnant and underrepresented outside of Japan for a long time, and a brilliant first attempt by developer MoaCube which I hope is but the first of many more to come.

Cinders is a colorful, emotionally-vibrant Visual Novel, starring Cinders, a wide-eyed, fiery-red, female protagonist. Cinders is about to embark on a journey—a journey of choices. The story will most certainly bring to memory another classical tale of romance, intrigue, betrayal & the pursuit of happiness.Choices are the core gameplay element in Cinders. The choices you make really do matter. The world will unfold around you according to the decisions you make—and you will always be aware of how they affect what occurs next. The gameplay mechanic for this is that a budding branch will emerge from the corner of the screen to denote an event playing out that has been mitigated by previous decisions. This conspires to make a living world, where you’re not an observer but a participant.While choices are at the core of Cinders, they dance around the diverse characters. The characters are complex, disturbed, scarred, & much more. None of the characters are simply good or bad. They reach out and play with your emotions as if they were flesh & blood. The artwork in Cinders is colorful & vibrant. You’ll oftentimes find yourself looking at the background scenery, to catch a look at the swaying shrubbery, or the flickering fire. The soundtrack is diverse & emotionally fitting to each scene as it unfolds. It’s easy to get lost in the simple background melodies.Cinders has a full screen option, with the option to choose screen ratio. The game looked great on a 30” screen at a 16:10 ratio playing in full screen mode.In conclusion, Cinders is loosely based on one of the classics, & most certainly worth a look if you’re interested in the Visual Novel genre. It will make your heart tingle & your nerves race as you take an emotional journey with Cinders.9/10

												Although it is a retelling of the classic fairytale Cinderella, the new approach makes it seem like another story altogether.Genre: Fantasy/AdventureDuration: 2 to 3 hours for one ending; 10 to 15 hours for all endings.Developed by: MoaCube, 2012By playing as the namesake protagonist, you are introduced to a fantasy world in which you must deal with your stepmother and stepsisters at first, later meeting nobility, fairies, salesmen and townsfolk. You do so through choices and map movement intermissions in the narrative. So as not to leave you confused, the game flashes a wooden branch icon on the upper right corner of the screen everytime a previous choice is showing its consequence.Cinders is structured so as to give your choices an aspect of freedom: there are not correct choices and you will always reach a satisfying ending that reflects your behaviour throughout the story. This means one single playthrough will last for about two hours, but one ending is just a glimpse of the stories Cinders has to offer.The greatest strength this visual novel has is probably its characters: no character is completely redeemed nor degraded. They are complex, round characters with motivations and goals that you can relate yourself to, enhancing the moral aspect of the choices: each and every character has a lot to be explored, making for a consistent world with strong characters - and many strong female characters - and a sense that you are free to make your own judgement. This groundedness, however, doesn't stop the game from sporting a most pleasant fairytale atmosphere. The art and the music, through coherent design and stylistic choices, gives Cinders a fine identity and a unique feel down to minute details, such as small animations on the background and on the sprites. As such, it's easy to get used to the art style even if it's not commonly used in visual novels. Such attention to identity helps in the establshment of an emotional link between you and Cinders' world.If only fow how bold it is, Cinders is a must for anyone who appreciates story-driven experiences with complex characters and a lot of room for the player to decide what happens next.Positive:*Great fairytale impression*Many choices and many endings*Fleshed out characters*Music is comfortable to listen to and the sound design is adequate*Consistent art and worldNegative:*Short playthroughs. You might not feel the need to see other endings/epilogues*Though the game shows when a choice is reflected on the progress of the story, some choices are still lost in perspective*It's expensive

												Despite the idea and the setting, Cinders is NOT a fairytale story about mistreated girl getting her happy love ending  with the help of fairy godmother. Sure, there is a fairy, there is a ball, there is a Prince, there is a lost slipper (altough it's not a glass one, and she didn't really lose it...).What you get here instead, is a story about dealing with your broken family. Both, your Stepmother and your Stepsisters have developed troubled personalities hidden under masks of the roles they trying (or are simply forced) to fullfil, and it's up to you to chose what kind of "happy ending" do you want to get, not only for yourself, but also for your family. Will you try to work things out together and help them develop? Or will you destroy them, to get what you want? Or maybe you'll run away from everything and search for your Happy Ending somewhere else? Or maybe you'll become someone you used to despised yourself? Even though the story is set in stricte fairytale world, it portrays MODERN issues of many dysfunctional families out there. And that I find the biggest attraction of this game, along with very beautiful aesthetics. On the downside... The game felt like it lacked some more individual panels to look at (as this is what the gameplay is all about- to look at lovely pictures and read a story you can influence with the choices of your own ). Possible romance options could have been developed much further ( 'cmon! You give us 3 handsome dudes and make us lick the window instead of touching the shinies >.< ! ). And unfortunately,  there is no voice-acting, at all. All this makes me feel that 15,99€ is way to expensive for the content it offers. Even though, I still give Cinders thumbs up \o/.

												What initially drew me to Cinders was the combination of the female protagonist, visual novel category, and the lovely artwork. From the looks of it, Cinders seemed like it would be a wonderful game, and it definitely delivered! I just started my second playthrough, and I have been loving every minute of gameplay.First, I absolutely must rave about the gorgeous art by Gracjana Zielinska! The character designs were unique and stunning, and the backgrounds were lavish and interesting. I loved how little details would appear or move in the background - that gave the graphics a "little something" extra to catch the eye! I could not get enough of the beautiful visuals and tried to research if she had done work on other games. I found out about Solstice, a mystery thriller visual novel coming soon, and Phantasmat, a hidden objects game. I am much more into visual novels, but the artwork alone is compelling me to give Phantasmat a chance also!Second, the gameplay placed player choice front and center, and especially in a visual novel, I appreciated this greatly. Choices were frequent and truly affected the story; the "Rewards" section from the game's menu lets you see how many of the variants you've explored to the ending, and in my ending, I've only explored 25% so far, so there is still a lot for me to experience! I did do some saving/loading to see what would happen with certain choices and was very pleased with the level of difference I discovered. In addition, certain choices add adornments to the menu page - this made game progress even more exciting because I wanted to see what else would be added where. :) ... and it brought out the completionist in me! I am excited to unlock all the endings and as many variants as I can.Third, the characters were unpredictably rich. Coming into a fairytale-inspired game, I expected the same character tropes, but while the characters were similarly-situated, they were far deeper than the superficial Cindarella cast I was used to! Cinders, for example, can be played to be quite pragmatic, or pig-headed, or honest, or devious, or a mix of the aforementioned, and based on my ending, I think the choice of these traits truly affects the outcome of the game. Madame Ghede was a favorite character of mine - I wanted to know so much more about her! She was enigmatic and wise, revealing a hint of the effects of what seemed to me a very detailed life. The stepmother (Carmosa) and step-sisters (Sophia and Gloria) were also multi-faceted, and there was more than meets the eye to Captain Perrault, as well.The game's soundtrack suited it perfectly -- it was not overbearing, but rather complementary. Chimes indicated decisions, and subtle pieces (like at the Lake) would round out an enchanting experience. I wish the soundtrack had been included in a bundle because it would be a wonderful way to relax. :)If you like visual novels, female protagonists, gorgeous artwork, fairytales, lots of choice that affects the ending, and a hint of romance, I highly recommend this game. If you adore Gracjana Zielinska's artwork (like I now do), you should also check out the upcoming visual novel from the same developer (Moacube) Solstice and the hidden objects game from Big Fish, Phantasmat. Enjoy!

												I originally had this game on my wishlist based on the art style alone. Turns out, it's a re-imagining of the tale of Cinderella. And it is a visual novel, where your choices have an actual impact on the story.Graphics / art - 5/10Let me get this out of the way since this is what first pulled me in. Mmmm ... not that impressive at the end of the day. Most of the characters look a little weird, and there's just not much animation. I know it's a visual novel, but it feels like they could have done a little more. So it's not bad, just not quite up to its potential in this area.Story / characters - 8/10The story itself is slightly adapted, and I have to say the developers did a great job. The wicked stepmother and the two evil stepsisters are actual characters with personalities, and through the story you can understand some of the reasons why they behave as they do. Truly a tremendous spin on a stale old tale.The developers also get into why there is a ball, which is pretty interesting.The most annoying character is probably Cinders herself. In some ways she behaves like any normal person in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ situation would. However, other times she's a bit whiny and preachy.My favorite character was actually the stepmother. She's less of a demon when you get to know her reasoning and motivations. And her drive is impressive.The side characters beyond the main ones (Cinders and her step-family being the core characters), are less interesting, and it seems like there are some interesting mysteries into their backgrounds that unfortunately don't get fleshed out. Like what the relationship is between Cinder's mother and some of the other side characters. What happened to Cinder's mother?Gameplay - 10/10As with most visual novels, it's mostly reading. However, at key points you get to make decisions. I wish I had read about the game before playing to better appreciate the impact of decisions. It would have let me know how important it is to use all of your (I think) 10 save slots so that you don't have to restart the story from the beginning to find all the endings.Basically, you can be good, neutral or evil based on your decisions. And your decisions impact your route to the ball, which suitor you end up with, and whether you're even happy at the end. I overwrote a lot of my old saves as I went along, so I was really limited in my endings. However, I think there are a total of about 12 variations.Pretty incredible, eh? The game itself isn't amazing, but when you realize how the developers freshened up the source material, you can't help but be impressed!8/10

												Do you want to pay money for a game with an underlying narrative about how abusers are kinda right and abuse victims should feel bad for taking appropriate action?  No amount of witty dialogue could cover up the inherently bad-- and at times disturbing-- game writing.  The game promised to add character depth to a familiar story, and it did-- to a point.  The stepsisters have a dynamic consistent with being raised by a manipulative, abusive mother who plays them against each other.  Lady Carmosa, the stepmother, is emotionally abusive in a realistic way.  Like many abusive people, she makes sure to micromanage the people that she's abusing, put them down, and try tell them constantly that they need her to treat them this way because of how pitiful/stupid/etc. they are.  Cinders mentions in the dialogue that she believes that Lady Carmosa is capable of killing, and it's implied in Carmosa's dailogue that she may have killed her second husband, so she represents a physical danger as well.There's a point in the dialogue where Cinders is speaking to someone who knew her late mother.  It has already been established that her stepmother is abusive.  Cinders explains that she believes that she-- not her stepmother-- is the legal inheritor of the family estates.  I chose the option for wanting to get an attorney to get my house back.  Mom's friend promptly gave me a guilt trip about the "consequences" of such a harsh act when my stepmother was just keeping the family fortune together.  You know, the family fortune that wasn't even legally hers that she's only using to benefit herself.  Given the more realistic take on abuse dynamics that the writers had so far, I figured that this was intentional.  Abuse victims often hear similar things from third parties about why their husband/parent/etc. isn't such a bad person and they should be grateful.  I waited for the protagonist to have an opportunity to confront this clearly inappropriate behaviour.Nope.  Wasn't happening.Every time the option for getting an attorney to get my (expletive) house back came up, I clicked it.  Every time, I got an NPC guilt trip and dialogue to make sure that I knew that-- although there are officially no wrong choices in this game-- I had made a wrong choice.  Bad, BAD player wanting people to get stolen property back from their abuser through appropriate legal channels.  How could I!  No matter how many times you choose that option, you will not have the opportunity to seek legal assistance to get the family house which you believe you're the legal inheritor of back.  There's also this little bit of talking to herself that Cinders has about how she's materially better off than most of the women in town so maybe she should be grateful for the life that her stepmother has given her.  You know, because if an abusive person takes our stuff we should be grateful to the abuser for what they've deigned to give us.I played through the game just to be sure that there wasn't, you know, some upcoming branch in which the game would deal with the mess it made.  Nope.  It's sure as hell not getting a second play through.

												Cinders is one of my all-time favorites.  I've played it a few times over the past couple years - whenever I feel like being whisked away into this magical, yet very realistic, fairytale world, and it never fails to make me smile.  It's always the first game I recommend to my friends that like choice driven VNs or fairytales.The scenes are beautifully drawn in a sort of pastel style with vibrant colors to help set the mood.  The music is good too and very immersive.  Most importantly, the story is well-written.  The language can be a bit over-wrought at times, but that just adds to the old fairytale/literature feel.There are quite a few ways the story can go, depending on your choices, and it's not always clear which choice made the diffference, but that's part of the charm for me.  It's not necessarily about where you wind up (it's definitely possible to get an unsatisfying ending), but about the journey of how you got there.  Each time I play, I feel like I learn something new about the characters and the world.  There were actually whole storylines I didn't even know existed on my first playthrough that made it pretty fun to play again.  Most of the characters are pretty intricate and more than willing to give you their soliliquy on life if you prod them the right way... or offer you a brutally scathing retort if you don't.  A few of them are really funny too!  Best of all, Cinders, herself, is a pretty relatable and empowering character with her own quirks and insecurities.  I could definitely see myself in her shoes (or glass slippers) if I lived in her fairy world.  Thanks to this game, I can imagine that I really am for a little while.

												Cinders is a visual novel that is based on the fairy tale we all know, Cinderella, and I thoroughly enjoyed every moment of playing it. It's certainly no fabricated Disney setup though, as it has a more mature take on the story, some of which involve politics, psychological wounds, social discrimination, etc., but still retains the light-hearted feeling of fantasy from the original.Pros: The lovely, rustic art style, one of the first things to catch my attention: a right mix of dark and heavy, as well as stunning, colorful fairy tale scenery, which creates the perfect atmosphere for the story's theme The music is a masterpiece, from the sound effects to the background music that plays on each scene: lovely to listen to, yet not too overwhelming to distract you from your immersion Beautiful dialogue you wouldn't want to skip, with just enough suspense that can't make you stop reading The subtle animations, from the way the flowers would sway to the wind, etc A handful of amazing characters, well-written so you could actually sympathize with them, even the antagonists The variety of choices given to you, and the many, multiple endings you could choose to unfold with them: high replay value because of this, you could be a charming and innocent Cinders in one playthrough, and a deviously cunning one the next As with most VNs, involves romance options, but is written so well that it makes said options neither a necessity nor the main driving force of the story, but only as a 'side quest', and focuses more on heavier themes More than enough endings: you are left with four main endings, as well as many different sub-endings under each one Provides you with a hefty amount of hours to complete, or read from start to end Has a feature wherein you can skip through parts you have already read, to explore the different outcomes Easy to obtain achievements, got to 100% in no timeCons: Some of the dialogues are... For lack of a better term, awkward, and a few moments are too cringe-worthy cliché Lack of, or rushed character development: pacing feels off somehow, and it gives you a feeling that everything is happening too fast Typos in some dialoguesThis is the first visual novel I have played, finished to the very end and tried to get all possible endings I can. For people like me who are not that fond of anime VNs, and have a particular interest in similar themes, this game is definitely worth trying out. Can't wait to try out other VNs from MoaCube~Overall Rating:8.5/10

												Amazing game, and I say that as someone who doesn't normally play visual novels because: a) they are usually drawn in the style of anime, and b) they are usually dating sims -- I find neither of those two things particularly appealing. This game, however, is not even close to being a dating sim (although there are different romance options you can choose to pursue) and the art style is miles away from anime and very beautiful.The story is a retelling of the Cinderella fairytale with a lot more depth, featuring well-rounded characters, complicated familial relations and meaningful choices. It emphasizes the extent to which characters' personal choices are limited by/the product of their circumstances and surroundings. The wicked stepmother and stepsisters are not simple archetypal chracters but complex figures with motivations and agendas that arise from their life circumstances. The main character Cinders, the young woman who lives as a servant in her own house, is trying to take destiny in her own hands and break free from her current circumstances, but cannot do so without outside help. The game makes a point: despite her desire to be independent and have agency, her available options are nevertheless to some extent the product of particular conditions that are outside of her influence (of her father marrying as he did, of her mother ensuring Cinders gets help when she needs it, etc). The writting is very good and the choices in the game are meaningful; I found replaying the game to explore different results very interesting. The first playthrough takes about 3 hours, while subsequent playthroughs can be made a lot shorter as there's an option to skip through dialogues that you've read in previous playthroughs. Definitely recommended for people who love good stories and don't mind reading a bunch.

												PROS- Cinders's personality is up to the player via dialogue choices--> Consistency is rewarded, while random personality choices don't serve as well- The art is beautiful, from the backgrounds to the characters- Morality is ambiguous, unlike what you expect from fairy tales- 4 different endings, all with many variations- The dialogue flows well and is interesting to follow- The stepsisters and stepmother are relatable, vulnerable people with real problems- Branches in the storyline feel like they matter for the events that happen no matter what- Two different forces of magic can help Cinders for the ball--> Both have a connection with Cinders's mother and provide different background info respectively- All the characters have issues to work out, the relationships Cinders makes from the player choices feel like they develop in a realistic way; nothing feels forced, like in the fairy tale- 3 different goals for Cinders, not just marrying the prince and living happily ever after- 3 different love interests- Can re-watch endings and variations after you unlock them, very high replay value- Skip function for dialogue you have already read- No tedious stat building!! :)CONS- Cinders's name... It's a bit difficult to take a scene seriously sometimes when characters call her "Cinders"- The game doesn't tell you what personality you have stacked or what progress your relationships are...so sometimes it's hard to know how to progress and confusing if a certain dialogue option doesn't work--> Leads to lots of trial and error- Failing to get the variation you want can be a bit frustrating for completionists- The music isn't too memorable- No homosexual romances, all 3 love interests are male- No customization of how Cinders looks- No voicesThis is a wonderful, extensive visual novel and possibly one of the best I've ever played. I've always criticized Cinderella as a character for being one of the most passive protagonists in the history of fairy tales, but in this game you can make her to be the woman you always wanted her to be. She also doesn't always have to marry the prince and sometimes the ending isn't going to be happy. You could even die and have no one mourn over you. The possibilities are vast, giving it lots of replay value. All the art is gorgeous to look at as well so oftentimes I just stop reading and take in the scene.The developers were right in advertising this game as a "mature" take on the fairy tale, as all the characters are ambiguous. You can never truly figure each of them out and most of the time, they will surprise you. The game does a wonderful job of consistently claiming that no one is so simple as "good" or "evil" and even the kingdom is going through a metamorphosis if you pay attention to the Prince's plot. Speaking of which, the writing is downright brilliant and atmospheric since it is a western visual novel. There are unfortunately no voices, but little nuances in what the characters say give your imagination plenty to give the characters voices of your own.If you enjoy visual novels with emphasis on dialogue choices, protagonist identity, relationships, and no stat building, definitely buy this game. I hate tedious stat building myself and much prefer making decisions through dialogue. All relationships are accessible provided you have made the choices to develop them; they don't rely on you being "cute" enough or "intelligent" enough. Despite my glowing recommendation however, Cinders is by no means perfect and I eagerly await anything else the developers have building off of this amazing genre.

												I enjoyed this game and got a number of hours out of it between multiple ending playthroughs (free flow and some with a guide to finish a few missed options).  My one caveat is that you should snag this game on sale or as part of a bundle, as I'm not sure most people will find it justifies its full price.First, you should know that this game is a lot of reading relative to the interaction time.  As the game warns you about in the begining, this is more like a book where you can make some choices to change the ending, rather than a typical point-n-click story where you are making choices constantly.  Luckily, it has a very nice "fast forward" option for skipping dialgoue you've already seen on playthroughs, which is something that is lacking in many similar games and is amazingly wonderful if you're hunting down other endings.I like the concept of this game; building my own Cinders' personality and making my own choices and creating my own ending.  I also liked the take on the stepsisters as more than just evil sadists, and actually was fond of Sophie in particular.  It is a nice retake on a fairy tale in a less black & white perspective, especially since you can deivate significantly from the classic tale by making Cinders "bad" or reject the prince, etc.The art is also beautiful, although I wish there had been more than a few backdrops, and a few characters whose faces and arms where animated.  I do like that there was some movement and facial expression over static art, just to keep things interesting through a lot of dialgoues boxes with otherwise identical visuals.  But like anything good, I want more than just a small taste of it!The dialgue can be repetative, cliche, and predictible, but I didn't think it was totally awful (there was even a joke about the Captain's belts that genuinely made me laugh out loud).  Could it have been better?  Sure.  Did I find it turn me off from the game?  Nah.  Another review also complained that the writing was too blatant and the foreshadowing too obvious, but I find this preferrable in these types of games, otherwise it is too challenging and uninuititive to guide the story in the direction you desire.  While the choices are not always clear how they will affect the ending and you don't always get exactly what you were aiming for in this game, some opacity makes the gameplay more interesting.  There is a fine balance and I think the game gets it decently well.The one change I would have made to this game would have been to add more frequent interactions with more choices.  They could have been additional conversation selections that were meaningless as far as the outcomes were concerned but valuable in terms of increasing replayability and creating more dynamic character personalities.  I think adding a number of trivial dialogue choices in between the "important" decisions would make players feel more engaged, break up the large amounts of reading, and make Cinders feel more realistic to each individual's vision of her.  There are already a huge amount of possibilities in terms of the endings, so I'm hesitant to wishlist for anything that increases those, but it would have been nice to have more options to influence the fates of more people in more ways.Overall, I quite liked this game and am glad I bought and played it.  It might not be the most amazing game ever but it was some hours of enjoyment, which is all I wanted or expected out of it.

Could it have been better?  Sure.  Did I find it turn me off from the game?  Nah.  Another review also complained that the writing was too blatant and the foreshadowing too obvious, but I find this preferrable in these types of games, otherwise it is too challenging and uninuititive to guide the story in the direction you desire.  While the choices are not always clear how they will affect the ending and you don't always get exactly what you were aiming for in this game, some opacity makes the gameplay more interesting.  There is a fine balance and I think the game gets it decently well.The one change I would have made to this game would have been to add more frequent interactions with more choices.  They could have been additional conversation selections that were meaningless as far as the outcomes were concerned but valuable in terms of increasing replayability and creating more dynamic character personalities.  I think adding a number of trivial dialogue choices in between the "important" decisions would make players feel more engaged, break up the large amounts of reading, and make Cinders feel more realistic to each individual's vision of her.  There are already a huge amount of possibilities in terms of the endings, so I'm hesitant to wishlist for anything that increases those, but it would have been nice to have more options to influence the fates of more people in more ways.Overall, I quite liked this game and am glad I bought and played it.  It might not be the most amazing game ever but it was some hours of enjoyment, which is all I wanted or expected out of it.

												Overall, Cinders was a joy to play. Some loveable characters, incredible art, charming music, and a fun retelling of Cinderella.Game Elements: First and foremost, Cinders is a game. It offers many choices to influence the outcome of the game, and the outcomes themselves are varied enough to offer plenty incentive for multiple playthroughs. The skip mode is nicely implemented, as it stops automatically on text you haven't seen before. However, it doesn't really do anything unique for its genre.Story and characters: It's good, but not great. Some fantastic character development with the sisters, but the love interests and the stepmother could use work. ---------------Spoilers Ahead!Carmosa, the stepmother, as you could imagine, treats Cinders deplorably, but we aren't provided with much of a motive as to why she acts this way. Yes, Cinders is not a biological daughter, but that does not preclude Carmosa from treating Cinders with respect. What's more obnoxious about this is that the game writing hints to the player that we should understand Carmosa's actions and respect her for it! It's little things, however, that make this a contradictory stance for the game: Carmosa could have fed her daughters smaller portions of dinner rather than feeding Cinders cold scraps; Carmosa's daughters could wear cheaper dresses so Cinders could wear something other than rags. It does not make sense for Cinders to respect Carmosa in this game unless she forgets the way Carmosa has treated her, and so the Carmosa as advisor ending makes no sense.Gloria and Sophie, however, are excellent characters with natural growth through the course of the game. Gloria is seemingly cruel but just trying to live up to her mother by copying her, and in the way loses herself; Sophie is bitter and cynical because Gloria and her mother constantly criticize her and so her self esteem is ruined. Cinders has the option to help both of them grow in the game by encouraging Gloria to explore her interests and encouraging Sophie to be proud of her intelligence and intellectualism. I was also impressed by their complex relationship with Carmosa, since they loved her for what she's done for them (climbing the social ladder so they could have a better life), but they also resent her for not letting them to be free to do as they wish. It culminates in the Grand Ball, where Sophie ultimately decides she doesn't want what her mother wants for her, and Gloria doesn't know if she wants it, either.Now the love interests. Let's start with Tobias, the childhood friend. He's got plenty of enjoyable one-liners and pleasant dialogue, should you interact with him. However, I never learn to trust him quite as much as Cinders does in his romance route. He puts his business ethics before Cinders's trust, worrying that she might ruin his reputation as a merchant. This is not a good start to a loving, trusting relationship. He wants to run away with Cinders in order to help her out in the traveler arc, but it would have been nice for his character development if we knew of some reason that he would want to run away from it all, much as Cinders wanted to run away in the Perrault traveler route. Maybe Tobias couldn't stand living in his hometown anymore; maybe he's actually not as honest as he appears, and he has some shady business he's running away from. I think my favorite route for him is Cinders as a noblewoman that marries her, as it seems totally believable that he would lend her a lot of money for social events and later marry her since they're in the same town. I do not like him as a lover to Queen Cinders, but that's because I'm trying to piece how they would stay in contact at court before he becomes a count.Oh, Perrault. So many conflicting feelings. My absolute favorite ending is Perrault as the lover to the Machiavellian Queen Cinders, as it is incredibly believable that she would continue to see him after she becomes queen. He's an interesting character, indecisive on whether he likes killing and duty, but he would be improved by being more human and less tropey. I believe the true happy ending is Cinders adventuring with Perrault, btw ;)And the Prince. So much could have happened! He was a good character with lots of potential! But then he focused on Cinders's looks at the ball... I would've liked to see him spy on her after the ball to determine if she was truly smart, if he was so committed to personality. He just needed more. And he doesn't deserve any ending where he isn't happy. He has to have at least a few flaws!I think the rest of the cast is sufficiently likeable, with the exception of Shady Character. He baffles me. Where'd he come from?And finally, we have.... Cinders!! I love that she's so moldable depending on the player's actions. She can be aggressive and a trail-blazer, or she can be docile and simple. And the text is sufficiently clear that I know the outcome of my actions on Cinders's personality before they're revealed to me. A+.-----End Spoilers----Overall, Story is 7/10, and Characters are 6/10. There's a bit too much going on in plot and not enough going on in character reasoning/development for why they act the way they act.Visuals and SoundThis is where the game shines. The art style is stunning! The characters are all beautiful, and the landscapes are all engrossing. For the average person, there's not much more to ask for. Now, from the perspective of an artist, there is more that could go into the art design. The characters suffer from what I like to call "Same Face Syndrome": they all have the same face and differ in how they dress. What if Perrault had a hooked nose? Or Sophie's lips were super thin and had no cupid's bow? This isn't a huge deal, but it is something that I would like to see addressed in future releases. And for a bonus: Tobias's left hand looks super weird. The soundtrack is really fun and fitting, but there could be more sound effects to provide immersion.Overall, Visuals are 8.5/10 and Sound is 7/10.EnjoymentDespite its flaws, it's still a very enjoyable game and a gem in the visual novel genre. I went and replayed it for all the different endings! I'd give it a total 7/10.

												Is the classic Cinderella a victim of her stepmother and step sisters, or is she a victim of her own inability to change her circumstances? Do faries steal people's agency in a literary sense as well as literally? Is the self immutable, or can it change in response to circumstance? If it changes in order to better survive difficult times, is that an improvement, or the shameful death of something precious? Is a democratic government merely an excuse for people to lie to each other all the time? In addition to offering a chance to ponder the above questions, Cinders is a fantastic exploration of both self-empowerment and self-destructive tendencies within the context of a classic fairy tale. It also has some fantastically witty lines and some good meditations on romantic love and its strengths and limitations.  For its message of empowerment, ambtitous themes, and fascinating characters, 10/10, cannot wait to play again.

												Basic Premise: Shape Cinderella’s character, attitude, and reactions to her upbringing and choose how she escapes. The many character trait and action choices that actually impact the story’s end make this visual novel stand out. I’ve played through it several times and still have not found all the paths.Music: Most visual novels’ and sims’ soundtracks have me hunting for the mute button, but this one is gorgeous.Visuals: Gracjana Zielinska’s art has a detailed, ethereal quality without becoming prissy or cutesy.  It’s beautiful.  I’m so pleased she’s returning for Solstice.Programming: I appreciate the ability to quickly skip through already viewed scenes with one button press.  All visual novels should implement this.Writing: *thunk**thunk* *thunk*  That noise, dear friend, is the characters’ dialog and the insights into their behavior being delivered with all the subtlety of a frying pan to the back of the skull. The reader is never left to infer anything. Cinders’ inner monologue or other characters will spell it out. During the first long conversation between Cinders and Sophia, they tell their back-story and motivations to one another without the reservation and self-protection that the back-story would naturally have bred.  It drove me crazy until I remembered Dostoevsky’s The Brothers Karamazov. Yes, the two works don’t seem to have much in common but bear with me. Like Karazmov, Cinders uses characters to represent a consistent type of person rather than how you and I would interact on a day-to-day basis. Once you go with it, they both deliver a good story and observations on human nature.  Boom. A 2012 visual novel saved by Dostoevsky.Writing: The banter between characters usually makes me smirk (Sophia and Gloria should have their own spin-off). The only exception is the romantic dialog. Excuse me for a moment, game, while I fetch some nachos to go with all this cheese. Fortunately, the game has many endings with no romance whatsoever.Writing: The grammar, spelling, and word choice are nearly perfect. Kudos to the editor.Female Characters: The writers clearly spent more of their effort developing the women. Cinders, Carmosa, Gloria, Sophia, and Madame Ghede all have distinct personalities and goals. Sophia’s snark is always welcome: “The only things missing from this picture is holding hands and singing. And dancing. Possibly in circles. In the middle of a flowery meadow. I think I might throw up.” I want an ending in which she and Cinders escape together.Male Characters: The men aren’t bad, but they lack the depth and care the women received. I won’t dwell on them (particularly since the developer has already addressed this), but here’s a brief run-down.  Tobias is a childhood friend who tends to deliver motivation speaker advice with the aforementioned frying pan; I want to like you, Toby, but you have to stop thwacking me over the head.  Perrault is a guard captain caught between duty and ethics; he is my favorite of the three.  Prince Basile is he least developed of the three, though the conversations between him and Perrault are good. He and Cinders discuss Levia Malich’s work in a scene ripped straight from Ever After, but other than that I enjoy their interactions.Bottom Line: I recommend this to anyone (not just women) who wants a strong, competent protagonist and enjoys tinkering to discover different endings. If you happen to have a snarky sense of humor, even better.

												The premise follows that Cinders acts as a retelling of the classic Cinderella legend, except that, in an attempt to actively subvert what is known as the "Disneyfied" 1950's animated film that can in many ways can be considered nothing more than glitz with a bit of a moral, this game allows not only for very distinct and non-black-and-white player choice options but fleshes out each character in new and unexpected directions.And I *love* it.Gone are the cookie-cutter Step-Mother drones Anastasia and Drizella and enter their respective counterparts Sophia and Gloria, and while Gloria does questionably attempt to enact her mother's will on the other two sisters, Sophia constantly snarks, talks back, and even actively rebels against both Gloria and Lady Carmosa, this game's (not-so) Evil Step Mother. This visual novel is all about giving us reasons to understand why these characters act the way they do, and obviously I don't want to spoil anything, but contrary to the popular notion that the antagonists (or anti-heroes in this story) are in cahoots, *nobody* likes each other. And despite her cruelty, even said step-mother has her issues, where most of her actions are explained, understandable, and sympathetic. (In my playthrough, I never got a good answer for why she treats Cinders like an old rag, though.)Of course, what to do with this information is for you to decide. If you feel like disregarding any understanding of these characters' own personal plights and personally attacking them whenever they get in your way, you are allowed this option. Maybe you want to pick a side in this sisterly conflict and get close to Sophia or Gloria; this is something you may do as well. In fact, participating in the subversion of this fairy tale is entirely up to you. You may wish to ask the fairies for help, marry the prince at the expense of your sisters' and step-mother's chances, and live Happily Ever After The End, assuming you can even reach that point. You can also be like me and revell in the story's subversive qualities, actively trying to understand and unite the sisters against their overbearing mother. It's all up to you, and no matter which path you take, the game's story never ever falters, because it's the story *you* want to make. It helps that the game's writing and story are (mostly) beautiful in each path and never fails to at least be interesting.Also, if you couldn't tell by the video and screenshots, the visuals and audio are top-notch. While the somewhat sparse and somewhat static character models can be a bit stiff in their animations (Cinders herself seems to be placed in a perpetual slouch, which, when you think about it, is kind of the point), the backgrounds are always stunningly gorgeous, with details that come alive despite through their hand-drawn aesthetic. The BGM makes up for its limited selection by being amazingly well-produced, even while synthetic (nobody would have expected a full orchestra from an indie studio anyway). The design here is elegent in its subtlety, with slightly differing text sounds for different characters' speech and dim auras surrounding the current speaker.I only take small issue in some of the design choices. For instance, I wish that the game wouldn't notify me whenever a consequence of a certain past decision is being played out. Every time I make a choice, its resulting difference is noted by a small plant symbol that appears in the upper-right corner of the screen. Often these are made up of small speech alterations that have little effect on the main story except for alterations in the character's dispositions and their own personal decisions, and sometimes I couldn't tell how a certain sentence would have differed had I made a different choice, or what choice with which that particular piece of text was even associated. Regardless, I'd much rather the mystery of how my decisions change the story be left to my own intuition.Also on the subject of choices, I wish the game wouldn't limit the ability to rewind through decisions made to see all of their immediate effects, especially if the feature's primary marketability involves important and lasting changes that won't necessarily take affect until much later in the story (and at that point, who wants to rewind that far back?). If the game wants me to shape the story the way I see fit, then there's really no need to limit this feature. I understand that certain decisions are meant to be important, lasting, and heavy, and perhaps a rewind feature would take away from this heaviness (there was a moment late in the game where I was confronted with a decision that would essentially determine the ending I'd get and I had to think very hard about my decision), but there are just as many conversational choices that have exactly the opposite effect of their perceived intention. I found myself in a conversation with Gloria on Day 4 during which I said some things I wish I hadn't, and, given the option to take them back, I probably would have. Perhaps this is meant to reflect the weight of real-life decision-making, but this game isn't about that. It's about player choice, and if I'm given a choice that, when chosen, results in the opposite of its intended effect (e.g. Cinders says something rude and condescending when I meant the comment to be compassionate and understanding), then I'd like the option to take it back.Finally, and least importantly, some of the writing in the game is a bit off. Cinders often goes about psychoanalyzing literally everybody she meets, and while this isn't chiefly wrong, since it supports the game's concept of fairy-tale subversion by revealing very real character traits in the people she encounters, it is a bit heavy-handed and perhaps a bit too obvious. Sometimes I wish I could figure these things out for myself without necessarily having Cinders tell me (and the character) directly, and there are other ways for Cinders to handle the conversations and actions she engages. There are a couple of blatant (but necessary) exposition dumps, but this isn't too horrible. There is also some questionable grammar, like the use of -t instead of -ed (e.g. "spoilt" instead of "spoiled") but this may be era-specific, or the use of a "than" in place of a "then" or a "where" in place of a "were."These are minor complaints compared to the quality of the game. If you want to play through it four times to unlock all four endings, it's definitely worth $20. Each playthrough will last you about 5 hours, depending on your reading speed. If you only want to play through it once, it's in the current Humble Bundle (as of writing this), or you can wait for the next big sale.

Perhaps this is meant to reflect the weight of real-life decision-making, but this game isn't about that. It's about player choice, and if I'm given a choice that, when chosen, results in the opposite of its intended effect (e.g. Cinders says something rude and condescending when I meant the comment to be compassionate and understanding), then I'd like the option to take it back.Finally, and least importantly, some of the writing in the game is a bit off. Cinders often goes about psychoanalyzing literally everybody she meets, and while this isn't chiefly wrong, since it supports the game's concept of fairy-tale subversion by revealing very real character traits in the people she encounters, it is a bit heavy-handed and perhaps a bit too obvious. Sometimes I wish I could figure these things out for myself without necessarily having Cinders tell me (and the character) directly, and there are other ways for Cinders to handle the conversations and actions she engages. There are a couple of blatant (but necessary) exposition dumps, but this isn't too horrible. There is also some questionable grammar, like the use of -t instead of -ed (e.g. "spoilt" instead of "spoiled") but this may be era-specific, or the use of a "than" in place of a "then" or a "where" in place of a "were."These are minor complaints compared to the quality of the game. If you want to play through it four times to unlock all four endings, it's definitely worth $20. Each playthrough will last you about 5 hours, depending on your reading speed. If you only want to play through it once, it's in the current Humble Bundle (as of writing this), or you can wait for the next big sale.

A lot of times I felt like the banter back and forth may not add a whole lot to the story, and doesn't create that much extra character depth... ultimately leading to longish periods of time between choice branches. This could also limit replayability, but there is a button to fast-forward through the dialogue that will still pause when there's a choice to be made, or when you reach a new scene you haven't seen before. A really awesome feature. Even though you can skip through quickly using this method, it still takes a LONG time to fast-forward through everything. The story is kind of that long... I think when I started a new story to get a different ending, it still took me an hour to play through even though I fast-forwarded through the majority of the story.The choices in this game can affect a lot, I think. Even though the majority of scenes STILL happen no matter what, the differences in the story with how the characters treat you (and even how your character treats them) provides a more personal feel... rather than picking options that feel out-of-place of your character, your character changes with your options. It's pretty nice in this way.Another really awesome detail this game provides is when you unlock achievements (which relate to the story and in-game decisions.) With each one you unlock, a change happens to the main menu screen... most of the time an item gets added to the scene. It's really a nice detail and just goes to show how much attention was put into this game. There's also a "reward" menu where you can see all the unique things you've unlocked, which is nice.Overall, the game is plenty long... I think my first play-through took around 3 hours... which is fairly typical. The long-windedness of some of the dialogue is the only thing that started to fatigue me. There are a lot of choices to be made to keep the interaction up and keep you engaged... the pacing is pretty good overall. When I first started playing the story seemed to throw in your face the fact that the story is Cinderella, which I found a bit annoying and obnoxious, but after that was over with I really enjoyed it. 												Cinders is definitely a departure from what you normally find on Steam. A stunning and interesting adaptation of Cinderella, Cinders is a visual novel and Choose Your Own Adventure story that captures, in a grown-up way, the spirit you had and the magic you felt reading as a child. The only two things creating this world are artwork and music, as the dialogue – the heart of the game – is all text. Surprisingly, I did not come across many grammatical errors, and being the English major I am, I was certainly looking. Editors have done quite the job. The storytelling was thoughtful and well-crafted; the writing was intelligent and contained more adult humour than I expected. In the short period of time it took to get through the first playthrough (roughly five hours), the writing delved into the pasts of a few characters and built them up to be more than just one-dimensional. Though most of the art is static, the odd flicker of the fireplace, shimmer of water or subtle eye and lip movements somehow bring it entirely to life. Though more colourful and detailed, the artwork does remind me of that which you would find in old hardcover fairytale books. The ambient music is absolutely beautiful and changes with each scene, though because it was the only auditory element it did have me longing for even more variety at times (as the songs are repeated); I wish the soundtrack contained even more. Though based on a traditional story with a subdued and passive female protagonist, this modern adaptation takes some unexpected and satisfying departures and shines more light on the complex relationships between the characters and Cinders’ struggle for independence and thirst for freedom. There is a focus on family and the conflicts between taking care of others and taking care of oneself. The heart of the story is finding one’s own path in life and understanding that each choice you make has a consequence, either immediately or in the future, for both yourself and those around you. In this way, the replay value of this game is pretty spectacular: it has four possible endings. And in all honesty, I think I am actually going to play through to see all of them.If you enjoy reading and visual novels, Cinders is absolutely with a playthrough (or four!).

												I picked up this game after never having had much of an interest in interactive novels, and can say that this game is very easy to pick up for those new to the genre. Having not played or researched many games of the genre, I can't really comment on how innovative this is within the context of its genre. I was thinking of postponing a review of Cinders until after I had played more of the genre, but I doubt I will do this in the near future. So here is a review, to be returned to if I do ever have something to add.A pretty great interactive take on a classic tale, the large amount of well thought-out endings based on choices made through the game lend well to the feeling of coming of age of the heroine, Cinders. It is also a refreshing take to give Cinderella more agency and control over her life, though she as a character may not realise how much influence she has. The endings closest to the original fairytale really felt well-earned as you really felt like you had to push Cinders to making responsible decisions despite the temptation to let Cinders be snarky and dwell on revenge.All-in-all the decisions felt quite organic in how they impacted the story despite the fixed events throughout the story and the number of game-influencing variables which is remarkable in any game. I thoroughly enjoyed replaying to find all the endings and the variants therein, and the eight save slots, fast-forward function and the flower indicator for branching story moments were a great help in this. It would have been nice to have an even faster way of scrolling or even skipping to the next decision, but what was there worked well.The music was great and perfectly suited to the mood of the game, and so were the beautiful painted-looking environments.  The touch of movement and change in lighting was also well done, present but subtle. The character design is very solidly well done, such that the few trappings of anime and manga in the style are not off-putting even to those who they do not appeal to.It is great to see this smart and well-made interactive retelling of Cinderella come to Steam where sales will hopefully help it reach a much greater audience.

												+Lots of choices+Well-written dialogue+Beautiful artwork-Controls seem a little off-Girly theme might not appeal to allOverall score: 8/10To begin, let me start off by saying that Cinderella is my least favorite fairy tale princess. Why? Because Cinderella cries and her Fairy Godmother magically fixes everything for her. Seriously? A crybaby princess? I think I’d prefer narcoleptic Sleeping Beauty over that.Thankfully, Cinders is not that story.Instead, Cinders is a game where you need to decipher the motivations and secrets of the people around you. You want a Fairy Godmother? Of course you can have one! You just have to work for it. You have to use logic to figure out what the best choices are, and, unlike some other VNs, the choices you have to make actually do make sense when you think about it. There are also many choices to make (I counted 47 on my first playthrough), so the game has plenty of re-playability if you want to get every ending. In addition, I found the artwork to be beautiful (or at least charming) and the dialogue was very believable (and funny at times).The two critiques I have of this game were easily overlooked by me, but I figured they were worth mentioning. First, the buttons are a little off. Intuitively, you would think that you would hover over the words for each button in order to make your choice. However, you actually have to be about half a centimeter above the buttons in order to click things. It’s not a deal-breaker, but it’s slightly annoying. Second, you’re playing as Cinders. Therefore, the game has an obviously girly theme. Even as a girl, I always thought that fairy tale princesses were too girly, and I never cared for them that much. I can imagine that, as a guy, this game might be a bit much. However, I would like to say that you can definitely still enjoy Cinders if you’re a masculine guy, as long as you’re an avid fan of VNs. 												TL;DR: Beautiful game with a lot of player agency but not labeled correctly by the devs and 'flat' romances.I really liked playing this game and I would warmly recommend it to any VN fans out there. That's not to say it's without faults but it's a very good take on the genre.Pros:- The artwork. It's gorgeous, it's original, it's great.- Player agency. You have choices and they matter (GASP!). You get to see the consequences of some choices soon after making them, other later on but it's so rewarding to have a story that can go in so many different directions.- Endings. No 'secret' or 'true' ending, your choices can lead to an ending that fully reflects the kind of character you wanted Cinder to be and that ending can be good or bad depending on your actions.- The NPCs. They are more than one-trick ponies whose one-sided personality is the end-all be-all of whom they are.- Info. The information you get from certain actions can be used later on, if you choose, leading to a lot of branching in how you play.Cons:- The labels. It's NOT an RPG. Labeling it as such is misleading to people who are looking for RPGs in the store. It's a visual novel, do not be fooled. (Yes, you take on the 'role' of Cinder but then EVERY game is an RPG and the label loses its meaning, not helping anyone anymore.)- The romance. If you're gonna add romance options, make them good. There could have been more depth to this aspect of the game as a lot of it was not as fleshed out as I could have wished.- The variation. With so much variations there's a lot of aspects of the story that are simply introduced and then not really explored, this is a real shame as some of them are really interesting.In conclusion: I don't have a lot of gripes with this game as I truly enjoyed it. There's a lot of consideration for player input and choices and if you enjoy visual novels, I definitely think you'll like this.

												Cinders is a very beautiful game, probably one of the most gorgeous games I have played.  It is not only an amazing visual novel with a dark, mature take on the story of Cinderella, but also contains elements of dating sims and roleplay as well.  I really enjoyed the wide ranges of decisions to make along with the variations of multiple endings.  Not to mention the dialogue is very well written, with very deep philosophical tones and also some comical moments as well - especially with a few fourth wall breakings.  All in all, this is a very good visual novel and certainly won't be disappointing.Pros:- Beautiful artwork - every character and background is absolutely gorgeous- Nice subtle animation - it really helps bring the novel to life and draws more attention - Amazing soundtrack - I would purchase the soundtrack if they offered it - Interesting Storyline - has a nice, dark twist to Cinderella while also including elements such as identity, self-empowerment, independence, decisions, and more.  It's not only a story, it's plenty of food for thought as well.- Variety of Decisions - there are so many to make and it really helps drive the story in different directions, which makes things all the more interesting.- Great Character Development - all of the characters have a distinct appearance and personality and it really shows not only visually, but in their dialogue.  It's fascinating to get to know them and it also helps them feel very real.  This part was truly amazing.- Replay Value - you get different achievements from different decisions and different endings, so there's a nice challengeCons:- The dialogue can get a little repetitive at some points.  There's some parts where a character will emphasize something and then it will be emphasized again and again.  This part makes the subject they're emphasizing a little too drawn out.  - Replay Value can feel tedious if already played through trying to get the achievements.  - Personally, I wish it was longer.  Overall, this is a very charming visual novel with many great qualities in terms of aesthetic artwork, intriguing storyline, and heartfelt character development.
